title: Brexit: Barnier Drives the Markets - Will There Be an Agreement This Week?
text:
© Reuters.

By Laura Sánchez

Investing.com - After Monday's falls, markets in Europe are largely trading higher on positivity surrounding ongoing Brexit negotiations.

The Telegraph newspaper reported, according to sources from inside the European Commission and the UK government, that there is moderate optimism about the possibility of an agreement on the latter's exit from the bloc, a sentiment echoed by Link Securities.

Experts at Link Securities point out that "the progress could be a hybrid solution to carry out customs controls, which would allow British Prime Minister Boris Johnson to say that Northern Ireland will not be left behind in a Customs Union with the European Union (EU)".

The Telegraph also noted that there is a possibility of convening another meeting before the deadline of October 31, if more time is needed to reach an agreement.

On the other hand, Michel Barnier, Europe’s chief Brexit negotiator, believes that "there are possibilities of agreement this week," although he did note that it was becoming “more and more difficult” to reach a deal before the Oct. 31 exit date.

Barnier stressed the need for a legal text from the U.K. that he could present to the 27 European member states at the European Summit at the end of this week.

Analysts at Renta Markets highlighted that an agreement is becoming increasingly necessary: “the Bank of England has reiterated its concern about what kind of monetary policy to adopt, because without a firm resolution regarding Brexit, we could not say what position to take with interest rates. "

An orderly exit would be a welcome boost the British economy. Earlier on Tuesday, the Office for National Statistics released U.K. employment data for August, which showed an unexpected drop in the number of people in work.

The rose from 3.8% to 3.9%, while fell by 56,000 in the three months to August, compared with an expected growth of 23,000 jobs.

The possibility of reaching an agreement, or at least the hopes of being able to reach one sooner rather than later, propelled the , which recovered from Monday’s losses.

The mid-cap surged more than 1%, while the dipped on a stronger pound and trade war hit mining stocks.

Analysts at Banca March noted that the fact negotiations were underway still diluted the chance of a hard Brexit on October 31, though it did remain difficult for an immediate agreement to be reached.
description: Brexit: Barnier Drives the Markets - Will There Be an Agreement This Week?
